participants.participant: Thomas R. Hill, Chief Communication Officer
Marcel Rohner, Group Chief Executive Officer
Marco Suter, Group Chief Financial Officer
Jerker Johansson, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Investment Bank

plist.p: Good morning, this is the Chorus Call conference operator. Welcome and thank you for joining the UBS First Quarter 2008 Results Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to UBS, thank you.

Good morning and welcome to the presentation of our first quarter results. You should be aware that there are forward-looking statements in this presentation and our actual results may differ materially. Additional information can be found in our first quarter report and elsewhere. Please take a moment to read the disclaimer on this slide. We look forward to answering your questions at the end of the presentation.

Thank you very much, Tom. As we pre-announced on 1st of April, we are presenting today a quarterly loss of 11.5 billion Swiss francs. Marco Suter, our CFO, will walk you in more detail through the composition of this result, including a summary of all the risk positions.

In my introductory remarks, I would like to primarily focus on all the actions we have taken in the first quarter to deal with the crisis, reducing risk, reducing balance sheet, managing costs, and strengthening the capital. Secondly, I would like to make a few comments on how we are prospectively going to manage costs and what earnings power we expect from our businesses. Thirdly, I would also like to make a few comments on our short-term priorities.

Let me begin with what actions we took in Q1. As you are aware, we recently published a report outlining the mistakes we made which led to the current poor performance of UBS. I will not summarize that report as you have already heard my views on this at the last set of results. But what I do want to highlight are the steps we are taking to ensure we grow sustainable earnings in our businesses and do not repeat the mistakes we have made in the past.

The first step, and one that has been in progress since last summer, is reduction in our balance sheet. We choose to spend a substantial amount of money, approximately 1 billion Swiss francs throughout the quarter in balance sheet and risk reduction. We achieved a reduction of our tradable asset inventory of approximately 160 billion Swiss francs. This accelerated reduction was and is critical to transition the business and the balance sheet as rapidly as possible into a position commensurate with our long-term priorities.

We are pleased with the progress we have achieved in this regard as this was a key driver to even exceed our expected Tier 1 ratio and to bring it, post the rights issue, to 11.8%. Since year end, we have secured additional equity funding of 28 billion Swiss francs and issued €1 billion of hybrid capital. Taking into account the rights issue, we are back to being one of the best capitalized banks in the world.

Risk and balance sheet reduction remains a critical part of our ongoing financial restructuring. Since Q3 2007, we have significantly reduced our total balance sheet size, risk weighted assets and our legacy positions. In fact, excluding the effect of positive replacement value growth, we have reduced the balance sheet by approximately 550 billion Swiss francs since June 2007. Marco will provide you with more details.

We are committed to continue to take down the level of risk and expect to reduce our balance sheet to bring it in line with our long-term plans. We continue to manage remaining legacy risks in a flexible and creative way in the best interests of our shareholders.

We continue to focus on reducing our risk positions; Marco will take you through the numbers in detail. But over the course of the quarter, we have reduced positions in our most important risk categories by approximately 40% through a combination of further markdowns and sales.

In the quarter, we also isolated a significant portion of our real estate related risk positions and created a work-out group to manage these positions. In addition, we are creating a special purpose vehicle where a further subset of these assets will be managed and our intention is to reduce our exposure to this entity over time in a way that reduces the effect of distressed market conditions on the core earnings of UBS and provides the greatest opportunity for shareholders to realize value over time.

You might have seen some reports about our work-out activity. We are pleased to confirm that we have an agreement in principle to sell 15 billion in market value of U.S. real estate related assets to a newly created distressed asset fund managed by BlackRock. We have reduced costs in all recurring categories, whilst we benefited from favorable currency developments, we are on a clear trajectory to reduce our run rates across the board.

The combination of risk reduction, strategic change, and capital raising leaves UBS with strong capital and clear path towards sustained earnings growth for the group. Although we have made good progress in Q1, we still have much work to do to restore the profitability, prospect, and the reputation of UBS.

How do we focus on efficiency? Our focus on efficiency is on three fronts; reduction in head count, reduction in general and admin costs, and the optimization of operating leverage. Cost control has a high priority in 2008. Considering the difficult market environment, UBS has strengthened its measures to reduce costs and increase efficiency. Recurring G&A expenses fell by 20%, personnel expenses fell by 16%; we will continue to manage these costs aggressively.

In order to resize the group, we are today announcing additional head count reductions. The Investment Bank will eliminate 2,600 positions. These are in addition to the previously announced 1,500 reduction which is now complete. This will represent a reduction of 18% from the peak level in the third quarter 2007. These additional reductions will primarily fall in the U.S. and the U.K.

In the other business groups, we will achieve planned reductions for the most part through natural attrition. We estimate that by mid-2009, around June 2009, total group head count will be reduced by approximately 5,500 people from the end of March 2008 and this includes the 2,600 redundancy from the Investment Bank.

We want to continue to grow our business and we will therefore add staff to our front office, primarily through hiring financial advisers and client advisers in Wealth Management. We target our cost run rate for the group to be at approximately 28 billion Swiss francs in 2009, or down more than 10% from current levels.

Let me make some comments with respect to the long-term profitability and shareholder value. I already mentioned at our AGM that our integrated firm will only work well if all its individual parts create shareholder value.

Our Investment Bank is making rapid progress in its repositioning. After the capacity reduction, we target that it has an inherent capacity to generate approximately four billion Swiss francs pre-tax contribution in a normalized environment. We will continue to invest in our front office in Wealth Management. Due to our significant investment in domestic platforms all over the world, we will now be able to continuously increase operational leverage.

We will complete the rebuild of some investment management capabilities in global asset management, to rapidly return to net new money growth. It is still one of the most efficient and profitable platforms in the industry.

In the second quarter we will continue to clean up the balance sheet and rebuild the Investment Banking business. We will continue to spend money in risk reduction and close out of legacy position. If our own credit spread continues to tighten, not unexpected given the increased capital strength and all the actions we have taken, we will of course see a reversal of the own credit adjustment, which we have disclosed separately for the same reason. Conversely, if monoline spreads keep going up they will automatically drive an increase in credit valuation adjustments.
With these comments on some short-term drivers, I would like to hand over to Marco Suter to guide us in more detail through the Q1 results.
Thank you, Marcel. Good morning. Before I take you through the results for the quarter, I would like to highlight the number of changes in our published report.

First, we have adopted the amended IFRS 2 standard which affects how we account for share-based compensation payments, including share option schemes. The amended standard better aligns the recognition of compensation expense with the performance year. This allows us to recognize most of the cost of share-based payments in the year for which they are awarded.

Previously these costs were mainly amortized over the resting period. We are presenting results today on a like-for-like basis, having adjusted prior year numbers to reflect the new standard. Second, in terms of presentation we are no longer using the adjusted expected credit loss concepts and instead are now showing actual credit expense or recoveries in the respective business groups.

Next, we longer show Industrial Holdings as a separate reporting unit. As we have exited the vast majority of our private equity investments, it really is more appropriate to report what is left of Industrial Holdings within the Corporate Center.

In the Investment Bank you will see that we have altered the way we report revenues. This presentation is more in line with how we internally look at these business activities, and it is also more comparable to how our peer group reports.

Finally, we have implemented Basel II, plus the new framework for attributing equity capital to the business groups within UBS. In our Business Group results, we have started to report return on BIS risk-weighted assets as well as return on attributed equity on this new basis. I will come back to the new equity attribution framework later.

When we announced the 15 billion rights issue on April 1st, we also provided you with a preliminary estimate as to where we believe our Q1 results would be. This slide shows the key financial figures for the quarter and compares them to the estimates used in our preannouncement. Overall, the net loss attributable to UBS shareholder amounts to 11.5 billion, in line with the approximately 12 billion loss we announced on April 1st. The results for the Business Groups as you can see were also broadly in line with our earlier estimates.

Compared with the preannouncement however, we can report significantly better pro forma Tier 1 and total capital ratios. The pro forma ratios are calculated on the basis of our risk-weighted assets as per March 31st. Its regulatory capital is adjusted for the 15 billion Swiss francs rights issue and now also for the €1 billion of hybrid Tier 1 issue which we have completed in early April.

On this basis, the pro forma Tier 1 ratio now stands at 11.8% and the total capital ratio at 15.6%. This positive development has three causes. First, the overall results came in slightly better than expected. Second, our risk-weighted assets were lower than expected; and third, we have issued during April a €1 billion hybrid which qualifies as Tier 1 capital.

The overall results for our Wealth Management businesses were affected by sharp declines in world markets, with the MSCI World Index for example, declining by 10% of a quarter in dollar terms. Currency movements, in particular the 12% weakening of the U.S. dollar over the quarter had a negativity effect on our invested assets base measured in Swiss francs. Note that 56% of invested assets in Global Wealth Management & Business Banking are denominated in U.S. dollars. This led to lower fee based income.

Non-recurring income also declined as clients reduced activity in falling markets. These factors combined led to total revenues declining by 7% quarter-on-quarter and 2% year-on-year. We have tightly managed costs in these businesses, but our flexibility on a quarter-to-quarter basis is limited. So efficiency gains tend to lack sharp marketing currency movements, pushing the cost to income ratio up during this quarter.

Compared with the first quarter '07 however, the cost income ratio has slightly improved. Costs declined by 4% from the prior quarter reflecting a slight reduction in personnel expense as well as broad based savings in general and administrative costs. As a result, pre-tax profit in Global Wealth Management & Business Banking at almost 2.2 billion Swiss francs was down 13% quarter-on-quarter and 2% year-on-year.

Invested assets in Wealth Management International & Switzerland declined by 12% from the prior quarter. 7% of the decline in assets was due to currency, and the remaining 5% reflects market performance. Revenues declined at a slower pace. They were down 7% quarter-on-quarter and 1% year-on-year, reflecting reduced recurring revenues on lower asset levels as well as lower client trading activity in choppy markets.

Costs were down 1% in the prior quarter. The lower performance based compensation expense was partly offset by increased personnel costs resulting from the hiring of over 240 new client advisers. Costs year-on-year are up 4%. Here you need to take into consideration that over the one year period, our employee base in this business has increased by almost 2,000 people, or by 14%. Pre-tax profit for the quarter at 1.4 billion Swiss francs was down 13% quarter-on-quarter and 5% year-on-year.

Revenues in Business Banking Switzerland declined by 5% from the prior quarter, primarily due to low interest income, with some of the decline reflecting lower interest earned on lower equity attributed under our new framework, and some due to higher interest expense.

Costs declined by 1% from the prior quarter, thanks to an 8% reduction in G&A expense. These costs reductions more than compensated the 4% increase in personnel expense following the annual salary review process in Switzerland.

Business Banking pre-tax profit at 540 million was down 10% quarter-on-quarter, but up 2% year-on-year. Wealth Management U.S. pre-tax profit on a quarter-on-quarter basis declined by 2% in U.S. dollar terms. This reflects flat revenues in local currency terms, a commendable result in current market conditions, and a slight increase in the cost base on increased head count.

In Swiss franc terms, however, operating income was down 9% compared to the fourth quarter, and the pre-tax profit declined 12% to 183 million Swiss francs. Despite the slight setback during this quarter, the cost/income ratio for this business has improved by 2.4 percentage points year-on-year.

Asset Management, pre-tax profit declined by 32% from the prior quarter primarily due to declining performance fees from alternative and quantitative investments and from our Brazilian business. Revenues were also impacted by lower recurring fees on lower invested assets. Revenues were down 27% compared with the prior quarter. Costs declined by 22%, driven by a decrease in both personnel and general and administrative expense.

Performance in our Investment Bank has deteriorated during the first quarter. Investment banking revenues fell 58% from the first quarter '07 due to a contraction in global fee volume. Advisory revenues decreased in line with the industry trend of a decline in mandated deals.

Capital market revenues were impacted by reduced market volumes in all regions. Equities also posted lower revenues in difficult trading conditions, with continued market volatility and limited market liquidity.

As to fixed income, currencies and commodities, I will discuss the losses and mark downs in a moment. Given this environment, we have worked hard to manage the costs in the business, and we have reduced expense by 19% quarter-on-quarter and 27% year-on-year.

Wealth Management International & Switzerland reported positive net new money of 2.5 billion Swiss francs, and Wealth Management U.S. contributed 3.1 billion resulting in an overall inflow of 5.6 billion for the Wealth Management businesses. The regional analysis of the net new money flows clearly shows that we have most effective in Switzerland. Here we have experienced outflows during the quarter. This was also evidenced in Business Banking Switzerland, which has experienced a net outflow of 1.9 billion francs during the quarter.

Outflows in Asset Management were 16.5 billion in the quarter. Institutional business had outflows of 9.6, which were lower than the previous quarter's outflows of 15.3 billion. In the Wholesale business, outflows in the quarter were 6.9 billion compared with only 0.9 billion in the prior quarter.

Overall, we believe that three factors contributed to our net new money performance during this quarter. First, personal wealth creation during the quarter was impacted by a decline in what we call liquidity events. These include initial public offerings and M&A activity of privately owned companies.

Second, our asset management business continues to see outflows in some of the more traditional investment styles. Part of these outflows are clearly of our own making because of underperformance in a number of investments styles, but part can be explained by the industry-wide move towards passive investments at the expense of more traditional investment classes. There was also a more general hesitancy to invest in mutual funds at this time of greater market uncertainty.

Third, the outflows we have experienced in Switzerland, and reduced levels of inflows experienced elsewhere are, no doubt, also a reflection of the reputational damage that we have sustained over recent months. The capital increase will certainly help in this regard, but we remain cautious as to the near-term net new money outlook.

In terms of immediate profit and loss impact, however, the net new money performance is of lesser significance. In this regard, the more important drivers are the development of the U.S. dollar and market performance. And we were pleased to see that in April have seen some positive development in this regard. The U.S. dollar was up approximately 4.5% and the MSCI Index was up approximately 5% in dollar terms and 10% in Swiss franc terms.

Invested assets declined by 13% to 2.8 trillion. As you can see, currency and market movements made up the majority of the declines. Net new money outflows were offset by assets acquired through the acquisition of the French asset manager, Caisse Centrale de Réescompte. As I've said before, in April we have seen a small recovery of the dollar and the MSCI Index. This helps our invested asset base.

Total operating expense for the Group declined by 12% compared with the prior quarter. The lion's share of this reduction was in personnel costs, which declined by over 16%, or over 1 billion Swiss francs. 926 million of this reduction came from the Investment Bank, a quarter-on-quarter decline of 31%. This is mainly a result of the weakening of the U.S. dollar and the pound sterling and the one-time credit of approximately 280 million resulting from the reversal of accruals in the fourth quarter '07 following the decline of the U.S. dollar and the share price.

The reduction of head count also contributed to the decline. The IB personnel costs for the first quarter include the restructuring provision of $175 million for the additional head count reduction program, which we have announced today.

On first sight, it would appear that we have made little progress in managing our general and administrative expense; this is clearly not the case. Absent an increase of over 400 million in legal costs and provisions, G&A costs are down 20% quarter-on-quarter. I will come back to this in a minute.

Total head count in the Group has increased by 279 people and now stands at 83,839. As you can see, we have continued to invest into our asset cargoeing businesses. In Wealth Management International and Switzerland, we have grown our employee base by 346, and the number of client advisers has grown by 243. Personnel turnover has not increased.

In Global Asset Management, of the increase of 276, 165 are in relation to our acquisition in France. The other increases relate to growth areas, such as fund services, real estate and the Brazilian Asset Management business. The Corporate Center head count increase reflects continued hiring into our Indian offshoring operation.

The Investment Bank shows a net reduction of 612 people. This reduction, plus the over 900 already achieved during the fourth quarter '07, completes the 1,500 job reduction program announced in October last year. Today's announcement of 2,600 further job cuts brings a total cut in the Investment Bank to over 4,000.

I mentioned before that we have been successful in reducing G&A expense during the quarter, despite the fact that the overall number has only come down slightly from the previous quarter. As you can see from this waterfall diagram, all core controllable expense categories within G&A continue to have a downward trend. Declines were experienced in most categories, and cost reductions were spread across all businesses. Absent the increase in legal costs as mentioned earlier, and these tend to be very lumpy in nature, G&A would have declined 20% from the prior quarter.

Before discussing our balance sheet and capital development during the quarter, we'd like to spend a moment to discuss our new equity attribution framework. This new framework reflects our objective of maintaining a strong capital base and to guide businesses towards activities with the best balance between profit potential and capital usage.

Previously, we reported return on allocated regulatory capital. Allocated regulatory capital was determined in an entirely formulaic way, and was calculated as 10% of risk weighted assets plus 100% of goodwill and excess intangibles. The new framework is less formulaic and involves more senior management judgment and involvement as to the appropriate level of equity required to underpin our various businesses.

To begin, goodwill and intangibles are attributed to each business on a one-for-one basis. With regard to attribution of tangible equity, the Group Executive Board considered a variety of observable inputs. First, we review the results of our internal risk-based capital model. Second, we review regulatory capital requirements, which are based on risk weighted asset usage, and also take into account differences in the Tier 1 ratio seen as appropriate for different businesses. Third we consider the balance sheet consumption of our businesses.

Based on the review of these quantitative inputs, the Group Executive Board determines the final equity attribution to the business groups. Any difference between the amount of equity attributed to the business groups and the total equity available is shown as a surplus or shortfall in the Corporate Center. We believe that senior management involvement and judgment is superior to a purely formulaic approach, and it emphasizes that focus on risk-adjusted profitability and free cash flow generation is a high priority at UBS.

Marcel has already highlighted that our program to shrink our balance sheet has delivered. Absent an increase of almost 150 billion in positive replacement values, which was matched by a corresponding increase on the liability side, our balance sheet would have reduced by almost 200 billion during the quarter. This balance sheet reduction, shown as the blue line on this chart, has also led to reduced risk weighted assets, which is illustrated by the bar graph.

From the bar chart, you can also see that the introduction of Basel II has resulted in a lower level of risk weighted assets for Global Wealth Management and Business Banking, and an increased level of risk weighted assets for the Investment Bank. On a like-for-like basis, however, the Investment Bank has reduced its risk weighted assets.

This now marks the third consecutive quarter where we have reduced our balance sheet. I would like to remind you that we have already achieved a reduction of over 200 billion in the fourth quarter '07, and over 50 billion in the third quarter. Adjusted for the increase in positive replacement values, we've now reduced our balance sheet by approximately 550 billion between the end of June '07 and the end of March '08. During the first quarter, we have reduced our trading portfolio assets by almost 160 billion Swiss francs. This was the result of a concerted effort to reduce our inventory both in FICC and equities, and we were also helped by the development of the U.S. dollar.

The balance sheet reduction also had a positive effect on risk-weighted assets. As of January 1st, 2008, the Basel II framework became effective. As anticipated, this resulted in an overall decrease in risk-weighted assets for UBS. As I've already said, however, for the Investment Bank, Basel II led to an increase in risk-weighted assets, while risk-weighted assets in Global Wealth Management & Business Banking, almost halved.

The chart shows the movement in risk-weighted assets for the group under Basel I from December to March, and then the impact of Basel II. The 20 billion risk-weighted asset reduction on a like-for-like basis between December and March was entirely achieved in the Investment Bank. Risk-weighted assets under Basel II for the quarter were 333 billion Swiss francs.

The reduction between Basel II and Basel I primarily reflects lower risk weightings for high quality, highly collateralized loans in Global Wealth Management & Business Banking, which contributed the most of the reduction. These were partly offsetting the declines via increased weightings for derivatives and for trading portfolio assets within banking book treatment.

Also, there is new chart for operation risk, which Basel II introduces. We will look at the components of the capital in detail on the next slide, but as you can see from this chart, Basel II had an overall negative impact on our Tier 1 ratio of approximately 20 basis points, despite the reduction in risk-weighted assets. Pro forma Tier 1 and total capital ratios based on March 31st risk-weighted assets increased significantly, as you can see from this slide.

On the regulatory capital side, you can see the main drivers for the development of Tier 1 and total capital ratios. As we already communicated, the gains from our accounting effects are not eligible for capital adequacy purposes, and did include the 3.86 billion Swiss francs related to the MCN, mandatory convertible note, and 1.7 billion reflecting the after-tax effect of own credit.

Further down on this chart, you can see the impact of Basel II, which I've already covered. On the risk-weighted asset side, it was a reduction of approximately 18 billion Swiss francs. On the eligible capital side, the impact was negative 2.2 billion Swiss francs, and is due to the deduction of intangibles and other items as introduced by the new framework.

The MCN became effective in Q1, after the approval from our shareholders. It added 13 billion to the eligible Tier 1 capital. The remaining 3.2 billion reduction in eligible capital came mainly from foreign exchange and other deductions, which include the acquisition in France.

The risk reduction initiatives in the Investment Bank, together with the foreign exchange effect, led to 21 billion decline of risk-weighted assets on a like-for-like basis. The proceeds from our shareholder approved and fully underwritten rights issue should boost our Tier 1 ratio by approximately 450 basis points. In addition, we have further strengthened our capital position, as I already mentioned, by issuing a €1 billion hybrid capital.

Looking at the exposures most directly affected by the U.S. residential mortgage market, you can see that we have reduced our risk profile very substantially. This was achieved by means of asset disposals, but is also a result of further write-downs we have taken in Q1.

In the appendix, we are providing you with additional information on most of these exposure buckets, there, for example, you will see how our current marks have reduced since year-end, and you will also receive vintage and ratings information.

Let me start with subprime. Here, we reduced our exposure over the first quarter to $15.6 billion, down from 27.6 on December 31st. Our residual subprime position consists of 6.6 billion in super senior CDOs, 8.9 billion subprime RMBS, and 133 million in warehouse and retained RMBS CDOs. The average marks in our subprime super senior CDOs were reduced to $0.33 on the dollar, compared with $0.58 on the dollar at year-end. For our subprime RMBS positions, the average marks now are $0.50 on the dollar, that's down from $0.74 at year-end.

Alt-A positions were reduced from 26.6 billion to 17.1 billion. Our residual Alt-A positions consist of 317 million super senior CDOs, 14.5 billion in AAA rated first lien RMBS, and 2.3 billion in other Alt-A RMBS. The other category includes all second lien positions and first lien positions rated below the AAA level. Our average marks for these positions are also significantly lower: The marks for super senior Alt-A CDOs were reduced to $0.30, down from 74 at year-end; the marks for our AAA first lien Alt-A positions were reduced to $0.77, that's down from 96 at year-end; and our marks for the other Alt-A positions now stand at $0.44, down from 60 at year-end. Again, you can see all the details in the slides we have included in the appendix.

As the downward spiral accelerated during the first quarter, we've also experienced some losses on positions related to U.S. prime residential mortgages. 229 million of these losses relate to prime super senior CDO positions, and 633 million to prime RMBS positions. Our fundamental analysis as to the impairment risks of these positions has not changed, but market sentiments have clearly deteriorated during the quarter making these value adjustments necessary.

Regarding our credit exposure to monoline insurers, here we were confronted with a reduction in the market value of the underlying assets, which we had bought protection from the monolines, particularly subprime assets. This has led to a 4.4 billion increase in the value of our credit default swaps, and hence of our contingent credit exposure to the monolines. The increase in our potential credit exposure combined with credit spread-wise and in further monolines, has resulted in an increase in our credit value adjustment of 1.7 billion to 2.6 billion. Again, you will find detailed information, by ratings, in the appendix.

Our U.S. reference-linked note program has resulted in further losses of 1.6 billion in the quarter. During the last quarter's presentation I explained the mechanics of this program in detail. Basically, as spreads in the reference pool have widened, the value of the assets we hold has declined. The value of the credit protection has increased, but not in the same amount. This has led to a loss of 1.6 billion in the first quarter, 1.2 billion of which came from subprime-related assets.

Our aggregate loss attributable to commercial real estate exposure was 443 million in Q1. Of this amount, 202 million came from CMBS-related super senior positions. You will see in the appendix that we have further split our exposure into super senior and U.S. CMBS/CMBX trading positions. Our total commercial mortgage-related exposure was reduced to 6.3 billion at the end of March, down from 7.7 billion at year-end.

Our exposure in leveraged finance was modest to start with, but we have continued to reduce it. It came down from 11.4 billion to 8.6 billion. The majority of the reduction was achieved in old deals. The average mark for old deals are now at $0.90 and $0.97 for new deals. Again, please refer to the appendix for a detailed breakdown.

During the first quarter, our inventory in student loans contributed approximately 1 billion to our losses. Here we have seen a 2.7 billion increase in our exposure compared to year-end. This increase resulted from us supporting the auction rate securities market, up until mid-February. We have since stopped supporting student loan ARCs in line with our competitors.

The markdowns taken mainly reflect different duration assumptions for the underlying assets. Prior to the market dislocation, these securities were traded and valued based on a very short-term average duration, 30 days or so. As a result of the market dislocation, however, and for the purpose of valuing these securities, we are now assuming an average duration of five years.
With this, I would like to hand you over to Jerker Johansson, who will summarize his plans for the Investment Bank. Thank you.
Thank you, Marco, and good morning, everybody. As you know, I joined UBS a month ago, and I wanted to take this opportunity to share with you today some of my initial impressions about the business.

What immediately struck me were the key strengths of the Investment Bank, specifically the global coverage and distribution capabilities, our tremendous emerging markets operations, and the overlap and linkages with the wealth management business. I've been really impressed by the quality of our client relationships, with both investors and issuers, and the strength of our equities and IBD business also stands out, as does all of the client-facing parts of our foreign exchange rates and commodity businesses.

As the incoming CEO, my first objective is to review the portfolio of activities conducted by the IB. In doing this, we are guided by the following principles: First, each business should have the capacity to achieve its return on capital targets; second, it should have future growth potential; and thirdly, it should fit our client focus strategy.

One tangible example of our portfolio review is our decision to exit the institutional side of the muni business, by either sale or closure, which we are announcing today. We will make further strategic decisions of this nature as we continue our review.

In parallel to the portfolio review, we're also resizing the business, and we have today announced that there will be a further reduction in personnel numbers at the Investment Bank. The people affected by this are in the process of being informed, and I am sure you will appreciate that this is not something that I, or anyone else, regards as a good thing. But it is necessary, and it's necessary that we have the appropriate scale and allocation of resources, including our people, for the business we want to be in, today and in the future.

As has been covered, we will reduce head count by a further 2,600 people, mainly through redundancies. These reductions will be equal across the seniority structure. This aspect is important, because it assures that personnel costs will be reduced in proportion to the head count reduction.

The second principle we have used is to be tactical about where we reduce head count. As an illustration of this, IBD and equities numbers will fall by about 9%, whereas FICC numbers will fall by about 26%. And within FICC, reductions will be much lower in strategic client businesses and much higher in businesses that are focused on capital rather than on clients. After this reduction, and allowing for some recruitment, the number of staff in the Investment Bank will be about 18% below the peak of the third quarter of 2007.

So, how will we measure our performance? As Marcel has mentioned, the group's overall ambition is for the Investment Bank to return to pre-tax profitability of approximately 4 billion Swiss francs annually. In addition to the announcement regarding head count reductions, we are pleased to confirm the agreement in principle to sell U.S.$15 billion of market value of U.S. real estate related assets to a newly created distressed asset fund managed by BlackRock. When this transaction is completed, it will allow us to both reduce the overall risk, and to shift risk capacity to our client-driven businesses.

So, what is the immediate outlook for our business? Well, while client activity slowed during the quarter, the medium to longer term outlook is for revenue opportunity in these areas to continue to grow. My first priority is to make sure that the UBS Investment Bank focuses singlemindedly on continuously enhancing our client franchise.

Secondly, we believe that the fastest growth in client opportunities will be in those geographies which are still relatively underdeveloped from a financial market perspective. We are exceptionally well positioned in these markets, being one of the top investment banks in each of Asia, Latin America, Russia, and Eastern Europe. I expect business with issuers and investors in these markets to continue to outpace business elsewhere.

Thirdly, it is clear that UBS Investment Bank benefits tremendously from the strength of the group's Wealth Management operation. These benefits come partially from cost synergies, but those are fairly modest. The main advantage is that ultra-high net worth clients need investment banking advice and products. This overlap on the client side has its greatest potential in our fastest growing geographical segment, Emerging Markets. I'm therefore convinced that the integrated model positions us ideally to capitalize on the need of our clients.

It's also clear that each business has to be conscious of the return it is making on resources. That is, realized return, net of cost, on capital, and that those returns need to be higher for riskier activities. I don't suggest that anyone at UBS ever really thought otherwise, but I have found that people had somehow lost sight of this fundamental requirement, being driven by revenue growth and the cost income ratio.

So, we're now in the process of introducing a performance measurement system that properly measures and assesses businesses in this context and rigorously allocates capital on this basis in line with the group strategy.

So, these are my current strategic priorities. In conclusion, I'm setting the framework for defining the portfolio businesses and I'm implementing changes in response to the immediate business outlook.
